commentBody: Bragging on how one's family has lived in the same spot since the 15th century also means that one's views haven't changed much since then.  Having just visited Poland within the past month, I see a nation preserved in Baltic amber in many ways:  hating the Germans for their depredations of the 1940s, hating the Russians equally for theirs after the war, and above all, hating the evil Jews who they were taught by their parish priests were the ones who killed the Baby Jesus and put Him on the cross.  I wouldn't give two cents for Poland's chances to become a modern nation.

replies.commentBody:
You accuse the Poles of hating the Germans, Russians and Jews - but the same shows through in your own attitude toward the Poles, as expressed in your comment.

Yours is a shallow characterization. Poland has always been in danger from its powerful neighbors, was victimized by them on a huge scale, and has legitimate reasons to be wary of them. And religious, sociological and political differences with respect to the Jews were not unique to Poland.

To say that Poland is not and never will be a modern nation is simply ridiculous.

These are very strong words about Poles hating Jews tournachondar. I happen to be a Pole and I am not antisemitic nor are my friends. And I do not hate Russians nor Germans. In fact, wife of Poland's president, Agata Kornhauser happens to be Jewish and, as far as I recall, they got about 60% votes last year.
So much about your unjust claims.
But, may be you feel better about yourself when you make such sweeping claims about other nationalities? Hater.
